awd_titl_txt: Promoting Scientific Explorers Among Students with Learning Disabilities: The Design and Testing of a Grade 2 Science Program Focused on Earth's Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
A robust understanding of core science concepts and practices is necessary for obtaining jobs in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) fields. Despite these occupational and practical affordances, few effective instructional tools exist for the elementary science classroom. Moreover, early elementary school teachers have limited materials at their disposal to promote a rich knowledge of science among the full range of learners. The purpose of this project is to address this need by designing and empirically evaluating a second grade science program, Scientific Explorers, aimed at promoting an early foundation for learning science among all students, including students at risk for or with learning disabilities in reading and mathematics. Scientific Explorers will be designed to improve students' knowledge and understanding of core science concepts. Recognizing the important role of early literacy and mathematics in science learning and teaching, this project will integrate core disciplinary ideas with critical mathematics and literacy standards. To support students as they engage in scientific tasks associated with Earth's Systems, this project will engineer the Scientific Explorers program around a guided inquiry framework. Another aim of this project is to develop and empirically validate a science assessment that measures students' knowledge and application of core science concepts and practices related to Earth's Systems. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Employing a mixed-method approach, this project will investigate the feasibility and efficacy of the Scientific Explorers program. Additional research activities will include establishing the reliability and validity of a second grade science assessment. Approximately 40 second grade classrooms from two different geographical regions will participate in the project. Using multilevel modeling and item response theory techniques, this project will address five primary research questions: (1) To what extent can teachers feasibly implement the Scientific Explorers program in authentic education settings? (2) What is the impact of Scientific Explorers on the science achievement of students in participating classrooms? (3) Do early literacy skills at the beginning of second grade predict differential response to the Scientific Explorers program? (4) Does responsiveness to the Scientific Explorers program differ as a function of reading disability, mathematics disability, or a learning disability in reading and mathematics (comorbid LD)?, and (5) To what extent does the early science achievement measure demonstrate technical adequacy (reliability and validity)?

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

 

The Next Generation Science Standards set clear expectations for improving science achievement across the nation by employing a learning framework centered on critical science ideas, crosscutting concepts, and the practices of engineering and science. Despite these heightened expectations, science outcomes remain low and display evident inequities across students from low-income households, students with disabilities, and students from racially and ethnically diverse backgrounds. To address these opportunity gaps, the Scientific Explorers project achieved two primary goals. First, we successfully designed a second-grade science program focused on meeting the instructional needs of all second-grade students, including students at risk for learning disabilities. Second, we tested the promise of the Scientific Explorers program to improve student science achievement in two methodologically rigorous pilot studies. Notably, results from both studies demonstrated the Scientific Explorers program had positive effects above and beyond comparison conditions and benefited students regardless of their initial science skill levels. Findings also showed the Scientific Explorers program equitably improved science outcomes for participating students, regardless of their gender, socioeconomic status, eligibility for special education, and race and ethnicity.

            Our team of researchers and curriculum developers from The University of Texas at Austin and the University of Virginia designed a science program focused on the Earth science performance expectations identified in the second-grade Next Generation Science Standards. The Scientific Explorers program is intended to be taught in whole-class settings within 30- 45-min science blocks. To showcase the extent of our development efforts, the following products focused on Earth science were developed, including (a) detailed teaching manuals, (b) student journals and activities, (c) expository science texts, (d) science vocabulary activities, (e) hands-on scientific investigations, (f) four simulation-based learning applications, (g) three science achievement measures, and (h) a digital science reading book. Because educational disparities exist in science learning, we designed the program to meet the range of learners, including students with or at risk of disabilities. As such, each lesson includes validated principles of instruction such as scaffolded student practice opportunities and routines of direct science vocabulary instruction.

            Developing and testing the second-grade Scientific Explorers program addresses several broader issues in science learning. First, there are few validated science programs. For example, the U.S. Department of Education?s What Works Clearinghouse has yet to review any comprehensive science programs for evidence of efficacy. By implementing a rigorous research design, we contend our efforts will pave the way for future work in establishing the efficacy of Scientific Explorers and programs like it that seek to promote the success of all learners. Second, to understand the relative efficacy of the Scientific Explorers compared to programs that offer less instructional guidance, we independently designed an alternative version of the program focused on the same Earth science content. In the project?s final year, we compared the original Scientific Explorers program to its inquiry-based counterpart. Results from this investigation strongly favored the Scientific Explorers program (g = 0.19 to 0.40) on all three science outcome measures. Implications from this work include the benefits of adding instructional scaffolds to science learning, such as teacher modeling, timely academic feedback, and direct vocabulary instruction. Such scaffolds can provide equitable access to critical science content for the range of learners in today?s elementary science classrooms. Third, by assessing moderation based on initial science, mathematics, and reading skills, we were further able to examine clear links between initial skill levels and science success. Specifically, we found some evidence that initial mathematics and reading skills were related to overall outcomes related to students? expressive vocabulary and science content knowledge. These findings suggest that future science programs should place a greater emphasis on directly teaching key science vocabulary, particularly for students with difficulties in reading and mathematics. Third, we examined differential effects based on student sociodemographic information, such as ethnicity, gender, disability status, and socio-economic status. We found no individual factors moderated overall efficacy, suggesting the essential ingredients of our program benefited students equitably. Because moderation analyses such as these help to unpack mechanisms pertaining to what works in science instruction, we advocate for future moderation work to better understand how science programs impact the range of learners. Collectively, our project included over 1,000 second-grade students across 50 classrooms from Texas and Virginia. Findings from our project have been disseminated in six peer-reviewed publications. Each manuscript was published in high-impact educational journals, including Remedial and Special Education, The Elementary School Journal, and the Journal of Learning Disabilities. Finally, this project involved 10 graduate students and four NSF-sponsored post-doctoral fellows.
